body_text:
The canonicaljson library defines "canonical" as "shortest possible", which means that Unicode characters don't get escaped. Firefox defines canonical as ASCII only. It is easier to change us. Last time I tried to escape the Unicode using Python's .encode('unicode_escape'). This doesn't do what I wanted, as it is intended for consumption by Python. That meant that it had strange behavior around quotes and backslashes.
I looked at how canonicaljson did its tricks. Turns out, it is just a certain set of arguments to the stdlib json. So I took the parts I wanted, and made it ensure ASCII. Easy.

title: Fix issue with quotes in canonicaljson output
body:
The canonicaljson library defines "canonical" as "shortest possible", which means that Unicode characters don't get escaped. Firefox defines canonical as ASCII only. It is easier to change us. Last time I tried to escape the Unicode using Python's `.encode('unicode_escape')`. This doesn't do what I wanted, as it is intended for consumption by **Python**. That meant that it had strange behavior around quotes and backslashes.

I looked at how canonicaljson did its tricks. Turns out, it is just a certain set of arguments to the stdlib json. So I took the parts I wanted, and made it ensure ASCII. Easy.
